Phyllis Amaral This informative review is focused on six selected topics relevant to those programs in which older paraprofessionals work with their elderly peers: (a) an overall mention of preventive mental_health benefits for the helpers via the provision of engaging roles; (b) the scope of roles of older paraprofessionals, including peer support, casework and outreach, community organization and gerontological encouragement, and other helpful roles in agencies; (c) the variability in recruitment, selection, and training practices; (d) the reasoning of indigenousness or helper-age similarity as positively influencing the effectiveness of older paraprofessionals; (e) the partial integration of elderly paraprofessional programs into the mental_health system; and (f) the limited amount of program outcome evaluations.
